C++: Has multiple binary compatibility standards (commonly Microsoft (for MSVC compiler) and Itanium/GNU (for almost all other compilers)).

Java: Native unsigned arithmetic unsupported. Java 8 changes some of this, but aspects are unclear.[1]

C++: Standardized minimum limits for all numerical types, but the actual sizes are implementation-defined. Standardized types are available via the standard library <cstdint>.
Java: Standardized limits and sizes of all primitive types on all platforms.

C++: Pointers, references, and pass-by-value are supported for all types (primitive or user-defined).

Memory management , URL: /wiki/Memory_management
manually , URL: /wiki/Manual_memory_management
Garbage collection , URL: /wiki/Garbage_collection_(computer_science)

Java: Resource management must generally be done manually, or automatically via finalizers, though this is generally discouraged. Has try-with-resources for automatic scope-based resource management (version 7 onwards). It can also be done using the internal API sun.misc.Unsafe but that usage is highly discouraged and will be replaced by a public API in an upcoming Java version.

Operators are not overridable. The language overrides + and += for the String class.
Only supports single inheritance of classes.

final provides a version of const, equivalent to type* const pointers for objects and const for primitive types. Immutability of object members achieved via read-only interfaces and object encapsulation.
